body.p:
This page explains the procedure to check whether a device has labels on partition..
Filesytem label

section.p:
To check whether a device has labels on a partition, log on to the server (server means- disk/devices?) and use the parted command as follows:sudo parted -lThe output lists all of the block devices. Following is an example output for /dev/sdc. with a single partition and a label of c0a8f502h000. Therefore the device has a label.. . . Model: QEMU QEMU HARDDISK (scsi) Disk /dev/sdc: 20.0GB Sector size (logical/physical): 512B/512B Partition Table: gpt Disk Flags:
Number Start End Size File system Name Flags 1 1049kB 20.0GB 20.0GB xfs c0a8f502h000
. . .

To check whether a filesystem has labels on a partition, log on to the server and execute the xfs_admin command as follows (where /dev/sdc1 is the partition where the filesystem is located).--code-- sudo xfs_admin -l /dev/sdc1 --end-code

body.p: The output shows if a filesystem has a label. For exampe, this shows a label of c0a8f502h000.--code-- $ sudo xfs_admin -l /dev/sdc1 label = "c0a8f502h000" --end-code---
If no filesystem exists, the result is similar as follows:--code-- $ sudo xfs_admin -l /dev/sde1 xfs_admin: /dev/sde is not a valid XFS filesystem (unexpected SB magic number 0x00000000) --end-code--
In this example, /dev/sde1 does not have a filesystem label.
